page.title: 03INDUSTRY-HAMSTERLEY FOREST
page.content: Hamsterley Forest was established as an early development of the Commission aiming in 1922 to build up Great Britain's strategic reserve of timber, Hamsterley particularly providing pit-props for the Durham Coal field. In the plantations there is a wide range of commercial species, concentrating on softwood timber; Norway and Sitka Spruce, Pine, Douglas Fir, Larch and Western Hemlock. Some areas are planted with two species; oak/larch. The major planting, commenced in l927, is now being harvested as mature trees. The forest provides employment for 13 men of whom 5 live in the forest and each activity is supervised by a head of department. In addition there are usually about 8 men employed by contractors. The production is now predominantly used for saw logs and pulping.
